title: Contributing to londonremembers
text: package uses Nix reproducible development environments.

title: Contributing to londonremembers
text: Install Nix Clone repository

title: Contributing to londonremembers
code: # Enter the Nix development environment nix-shell  # Inside nix-shell, run R R

title: Contributing to londonremembers
text: R commands run within nix-shell:
code: # Generate documentation nix-shell --run "Rscript -e 'roxygen2::roxygenise()'"  # Run tests nix-shell --run "Rscript -e 'devtools::test()'"  # Run R CMD check nix-shell --run "Rscript -e 'devtools::check()'"  # Build package nix-shell --run "R CMD build ."  # Install locally nix-shell --run "Rscript -e 'devtools::install()'"

title: Contributing to londonremembers
text: Follow standard R package conventions Use roxygen2 documentation Write tests new functions Ensure R CMD check passes 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes

title: Contributing to londonremembers
text: Fork repository Create feature branch Make changes Ensure tests pass Update documentation Submit pull request GitHub Actions workflows automatically: - Run R CMD check multiple platforms - Calculate test coverage - Build pkgdown documentation

title: Contributing to londonremembers
text: Three workflows run automatically push: R-CMD-check - Tests package Ubuntu macOS test-coverage - Calculates reports code coverage pkgdown - Builds deploys package website workflows use shell.nix environment reproducibility.

title: Contributing to londonremembers
text: need add R package dependencies: Add DESCRIPTION (Imports Suggests) Add shell.nix (rPackages.<package>) Update documentation/imports needed Run R CMD check verify

title: Contributing to londonremembers
text: Open issue GitHub questions suggestions!

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: vignette compares contrasts memorials London honoring three distinct groups: Men named John - examine common male figures commemorated Women (name) - assess gender representation public memorials Dogs (gender) - quirky baseline highlight commemoration patterns ’ll analyze memorials : Type (statues, plaques, monuments, etc.) Year decade erected Location information distinguishing factors

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
code: library(londonremembers) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(tidyr) library(stringr) library(lubridate)

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: Let’s collect data three groups. Note: may take several minutes ’re querying London Remembers website. demonstration purposes, let’s create sample data:
code: # Collect memorials for men named John johns <- search_memorials("John", pages = 10) %>%   mutate(category = "Men named John")  # Collect memorials for women women_search_terms <- c("women", "woman", "female", "lady", "dame", "queen") women_results <- lapply(women_search_terms, function(term) {   search_memorials(term, pages = 5) }) women <- bind_rows(women_results) %>%   distinct(url, .keep_all = TRUE) %>%   mutate(category = "Women")  # Collect memorials for dogs dogs <- search_memorials("dog", pages = 3) %>%   mutate(category = "Dogs")  # Combine all data all_memorials <- bind_rows(johns, women, dogs)  # Save for faster loading saveRDS(all_memorials, "memorial_data.rds") # Sample data for demonstration set.seed(42)  sample_memorials <- tibble(   title = c(     "John Smith Monument", "John Doe Plaque", "John Brown Statue",     "Florence Nightingale Statue", "Queen Victoria Memorial",     "Mary Seacole Bust", "Emmeline Pankhurst Statue",     "Greyfriars Bobby Monument", "Balto Statue", "Hachiko Memorial"   ),   type = c(     "Monument", "Plaque", "Statue",     "Statue", "Memorial", "Bust", "Statue",     "Monument", "Statue", "Memorial"   ),   category = c(     rep("Men named John", 3),     rep("Women", 4),     rep("Dogs", 3)   ),   year_erected = c(     1850, 1892, 1905,     1915, 1911, 2016, 2018,     1873, 1925, 1948   ),   location = c(     "Westminster", "City of London", "Kensington",     "Waterloo Place", "The Mall", "St Thomas' Hospital", "Parliament Square",     "Edinburgh", "Central Park", "Shibuya"   ) ) %>%   mutate(     decade = floor(year_erected / 10) * 10,     century = case_when(       year_erected < 1900 ~ "19th Century",       year_erected < 2000 ~ "20th Century",       TRUE ~ "21st Century"     )   )  all_memorials <- sample_memorials

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: Let’s start basic counts: Memorial Summary Category
code: summary_table <- all_memorials %>%   group_by(category) %>%   summarise(     Total = n(),     Earliest = min(year_erected, na.rm = TRUE),     Latest = max(year_erected, na.rm = TRUE),     `Avg Year` = round(mean(year_erected, na.rm = TRUE))   ) %>%   arrange(desc(Total))  knitr::kable(summary_table,              caption = "Memorial Summary by Category")

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: Memorial Types Category
code: type_table <- all_memorials %>%   group_by(category, type) %>%   summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>%   pivot_wider(names_from = category, values_from = count, values_fill = 0) %>%   arrange(desc(`Men named John` + Women + Dogs))  knitr::kable(type_table,              caption = "Memorial Types by Category")

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
code: ggplot(all_memorials, aes(x = category, fill = type)) +   geom_bar(position = "stack") +   labs(     title = "Distribution of Memorial Types",     subtitle = "Comparing Johns, Women, and Dogs",     x = "Category",     y = "Number of Memorials",     fill = "Memorial Type"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) ggplot(all_memorials, aes(x = category, fill = type)) +   geom_bar(position = "fill") +   labs(     title = "Proportion of Memorial Types",     subtitle = "Comparing Johns, Women, and Dogs",     x = "Category",     y = "Proportion",     fill = "Memorial Type"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent)

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: Memorials Erected Decade
code: decade_table <- all_memorials %>%   group_by(category, decade) %>%   summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>%   pivot_wider(names_from = category, values_from = count, values_fill = 0) %>%   arrange(decade)  knitr::kable(decade_table,              caption = "Memorials Erected by Decade")

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
code: ggplot(all_memorials, aes(x = year_erected, fill = category)) +   geom_histogram(binwidth = 10, position = "dodge", alpha = 0.7) +   labs(     title = "Timeline of Memorial Erection",     subtitle = "Johns vs Women vs Dogs",     x = "Year Erected",     y = "Number of Memorials",     fill = "Category"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2")

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
code: century_summary <- all_memorials %>%   group_by(category, century) %>%   summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop")  ggplot(century_summary, aes(x = century, y = count, fill = category)) +   geom_col(position = "dodge") +   labs(     title = "Memorials by Century",     x = "Century",     y = "Number of Memorials",     fill = "Category"   ) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: Top 5 Locations Category
code: location_table <- all_memorials %>%   group_by(category, location) %>%   summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>%   group_by(category) %>%   slice_max(order_by = count, n = 5) %>%   arrange(category, desc(count))  knitr::kable(location_table,              caption = "Top 5 Locations by Category")

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: Geographic Distribution Statistics
code: diversity_stats <- all_memorials %>%   group_by(category) %>%   summarise(     `Total Memorials` = n(),     `Unique Locations` = n_distinct(location),     `Avg per Location` = round(n() / n_distinct(location), 2)   )  knitr::kable(diversity_stats,              caption = "Geographic Distribution Statistics")

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: Based analysis: Representation Gap: number memorials men named John compared memorials women highlights potential gender imbalances public commemoration. Memorial Types: observe differences group commemorated (statues vs plaques vs monuments), may reflect societal values power dynamics. Temporal Trends: timeline shows group received commemoration, potential increases women’s memorials recent decades reflecting changing social attitudes.

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: Including dogs analysis serves provocative baseline: dogs memorials women, highlights significant gender disparities types memorials dogs (often emotional, narrative-driven) contrast formal political memorials Dogs’ memorials often celebrate loyalty service, themes may overlap differ human commemoration

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: interested memorial equity: Document gaps: Identify underrepresented groups time periods Advocate diversity: Support new memorials honoring women minorities Recontextualize existing memorials: Add plaques information problematic figures Create interactive resources: Use data like educate public representation

title: Comparing London Memorials: Johns, Women, and Dogs
text: analysis reveals patterns London commemorates different groups public memorials. comparison men named John, women names, dogs serves lens examine: Gender representation public spaces Types achievement deemed worthy commemoration Historical contemporary values reflected memorial choices Geographic distribution commemorative efforts Future analyses expand include: Racial ethnic diversity memorials Professional categories (scientists, artists, military, etc.) Memorial funding sources installation processes Public sentiment controversy around memorials
